titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Log Files (Grant and Project Proposals)
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Log Files (Grant and Project Proposals) FA734

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-08-11 00:01:57 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Log Files (Grant and Project Proposals)
did.physdesc: Log Files (Grant Project Proposals) are housed on 598 reels of microfilm, numbered L-001 to L-598. The first 146 reels are 35mm microfilm, while the remaining 452 reels are 16mm microfilm.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Log Files (Grant & Project Proposals) are identified by a unique Log File # in the Ford Foundation Archives. Log File #s are formatted similar to the Foundation's grant numbers (PA numbers).
Each Log File # begins with the letter "L", followed by the two-digit year, and a sequential number within that year. For example: L60-123 = Log File, 1960, #123
However, during the 1950s Log Files were sometimes numbered with only one digit for the year, for example: L5-123 = Log File, 1955, #123
Each Log File was recorded in a series of Log Books, hence the name 'Log Files'.

The Ford Foundation Archive includes Log Files dating from 1951 to 1995. Log Files were microfilmed by year, and numerically by Log File# within each year. However there are many exceptions, and generally Log Files from 1977 to 1995 were not microfilmed in numerical order.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be restricted from scholarly research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment.
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be restricted from scholarly research at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/RAC Head of Reference.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.
Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Log Files (Grant & Project Proposals) are indexed by the Ford Foundations Central Index cards, 1950-1996 (FA736). The Central Index cards provide Log File numbers only, not microfilm reel numbers.

The Ford Foundation's LINKS database (available only to RAC staff), from which the description for the 1977-1995 Log Files presented here originates, provides indexing to 1,811 Log Files from 1977-2002, although this is not a complete inventory of the Log Files from that period. 133 of the 1,811 documented Log Files dating from the 1990s-2002 are not contained in the collection at RAC.
Grant & Project Proposals (Log Files) from 1951 to 1981 are listed by Log File number in the Ford Foundation's Log Books.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Initial preliminary description is provided in this guide for the Log Files spanning the years 1951-1976 to facilitate basic access to the holdings until such time that RAC can conduct further archival processing of the reels. This guide will be updated with addtiional description once the material is processed.
The description provided in this guide for the Log Files spanning the years 1977-1995, originated from the Ford Foundation's LINKS database.
The description of the 1977-1995 files includes: Log Number, Grantee Name, Grant Purpose, and the description for select logs also includes associated Program Name and Program Officer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Types of records include: grant and project log files.

did.unittitle: L57-144: Staff study of the computing machine field - Ford Foundation

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also Log file L57-177: Program of studies involving an electronic brain (W. Ross Ashby); and grant file 05700090 (PA57-90), Carnegie Mellon University, SUMMER SEMINAR IN NEW DEVELOPMENTS IN BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes material on computer science, artificial intelligence, cybernetics, problem solving, and social behavior.

Interview notes by Richard Sheldon (FF staff), from discussions with scientists, including: Jerome Wiesner, Herbert A. Simon, Allen Newell, Robert M. Fano and Peter Elias, Warren S. McCulloch, Claude Shannon, Victor H. Yngve and Noam Chomsky, Walter Pitts, Marvin Minsky, Raymond Solomonoff, Oliver Selfridge, John McCarthy, J.H. Bigelow, John Backus, Donald Sayre, Henry Quastler, Eduardo Renato Caianiello, Donald Mackay, Colin Cherry and Arnold Tustin, John Zachary Young, M.V. Wilkes, Richard L. Gregory, Albert M. Uttley, R.L. Beurle, W. Grey Walter, Frank Honywill George, W. Ross Ashby, and Sir Geoffrey Vickers.

Researcher papers and project proposals included (in order of appearance): "Tentative proposal for Cybernetic Research in the C.M.E. Division of National Physical Laboratory" by Albert M. Uttley (National Physical Laboratory, Teddington, England); "Behavioural Sciences Research Unit, Studies of Neural Connectivity and Behaviour" by John Zachary Young (University College, London); "Rational Choice and the Structure of the Environment" by Herbert A. Simon (Carnegie Institute of Technology); "The Logic Machine, A Complex Information Processing System" by Allen Newell and Herbert A. Simon (RAND Corporation and Carnegie Institute of Technology); "Elements of a Theory of Human Problem Solving", "Problem Solving in Humans and Computers", "Current Developments in Complex Information Processing" by Allen Newell, J.C. Shaw, and Herbert A. Simon (RAND Corporation and Carnegie Institute of Technology); First Conference on Mechanical Translation" by Erwin Reifler (University of Washington, Seattle); "Tests on a Cell Assembly Theory of the Action of the Brain, Using a Large Digital Computer" by N. Rochester, J.H. Holland, L.H. Haibt, W.L. Duda (IBM Research Laboratory); "Machines as Behavioural Models", "A Note on Theory Construction in Science", "Errors of Visual Recognition", and "Formalization of Language Systems for Behavior Theory" by Frank Honywill George (University of Bristol, England); "Proposal for a Research Program Applying Cybernetic Principles to the Study of the Development of Human Mentality and Social Behavior", "The Cybernetic Approach to Mentality and Society", and "Thinking Machines", by W. Grey Walter (Burden Neurological Institute, Bristol, England); "A Framework for an Artificial Intelligence" by Marvin Minsky (MIT); and various issues of the journal Mechanical Translation.
